feed.title: Worship services - Trinity and Cores End URCs

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

entry.title: Trinity URC morning worship 16th Oct led bychurch members

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC morning worship 16th Oct led bychurch members
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
Welcome and lighting of peace candle (elder)
Kate to introduce David Reynold’s video
Call to worship
2 Corinthians 3:18 And we, who with unveiled faces all reflect the Lord’s glory, are being transformed into his likeness with ever-increasing glory, which from the Lord, who is the Spirit.
HYMN – R&S 489 Be thou my vision
Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
Short introduction to Compassion by Marian Drake followed by a video preparing us for next Sunday’s service for Compassion Sunday
HYMN – R&S 522 From heaven you came (Servant King)
Introduction to Bible readings We will now listen to our readings read by John Hillson and Lesley Bogart.
Readings
Psalm 139 read by John Hillson (seated)
John 9:1-11 read by Lesley Bogart 1 As he went along, he saw a man blind from birth. 2 His disciples asked him, ‘Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?’ 3 ‘Neither this man nor his parents sinned,’ said Jesus, ‘but this happened so that the works of God might be displayed in him. 4 As long as it is day, we must do the works of him who sent me. Night is coming, when no one can work. 5 While I am in the world, I am the light of the world.’ 6 After saying this, he spat on the ground, made some mud with the saliva, and put it on the man’s eyes. 7 ‘Go,’ he told him, ‘wash in the Pool of Siloam’ (this word means ‘Sent’). So the man went and washed, and came home seeing. 8 His neighbours and those who had formerly seen him begging asked, ‘Isn’t this the same man who used to sit and beg?’ 9 Some claimed that he was. Others said, ‘No, he only looks like him.’ But he himself insisted, ‘I am the man.’ 10 ‘How then were your eyes opened?’ they asked. 11 He replied, ‘The man they call Jesus made some mud and put it on my eyes. He told me to go to Siloam and wash. So I went and washed, and then I could see.’
HYMN – R&S 549 One more step along the way I go
Poem written and read by David Reynolds
HYMN – R&S 518 Father I place into your hands
Short Address – Made in God’s image
Video – “Made in God’s Image”
Offering prayer (no collection is taken up but prayer can acknowledge our gifts to God)
Prayers for the world led by Kate Yates
HYMN – R&S 117 How Great Thou Art
Closing Blessing
Blessing

entry.title: Trinity URC morning worship 9th Oct led by Rev Bridget Powell

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC morning worship 9th Oct led by Rev Bridget Powell
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
09:40 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder) 11:35 - Call to worship: Verses from Psalm 111
13:39 - Hymn: R&S 60 God who spoke in the beginning To tune Rhuddlan 344
16:08 - Opening Prayer and The Lord’s Prayer
19:50 - Introduction to the theme: Saying Thank You I have in mind a story from the Gospel Do you remember the story where Jesus met 10 lepers on the road They didn't come near but said to him - "Master, have pity on us" He told them to go to the priest and they would be cleansed There are 200,000 people suffering with leprosy in 2020 It can be cured now but there is still a lot of it around These 10 men did not have access to modern medicine, they would have gone to a colony, gradually lost the use of their extremities. However, they did as told, went to the priest and were seen as cured. Only one of them turned back to Jesus to thank him Do we always remember to say thank you? ACTS mnemonic for how to pray - Adoration, Confession, Thanksgiving, and Supplication What would you like to give thanks for today?
HYMN: R&S 302 O breath of life come sweeping through us
Introduction to the readings
Readings: 2 Kings 5:1-15 NIVUK Naaman healed of leprosy
Luke 17: 11-19 NIVUK Jesus heals ten men with leprosy
HYMN: R&S 492 Dear Lord and Father of mankind
Sermon: First impressions followed by time of quite reflection
HYMN: R&S 648 Jesu, Jesu, fill us with your love
Prayers of Intercession
Response: Gracious Lord, hear our prayers
HYMN: R&S 200 The Kingdom of God is justice and joy
Blessing

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 2nd October 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
15:49 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
17:32 - United Reformed Church 50th anniversary memorabilia 19:49 - Call to worship With the whole Christian Church, the United Reformed Church believes in one God, Father, Son and Holy Spirit. Glory to God in highest heaven: peace to all people on earth.
20:10 - Hymn - R&S 29 Father we love you
21:33 - The life of faith to which we are called is the Spirit’s gift continually received through the Word, the Sacraments and our Christian life together: Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
22:08 - Opening Prayers
23:58 - 29:00 - Introduction for all ages – joined together I would have loved to give each of you a piece of this 50th anniversary jigsaw but there is nothing more annoying than a missing piece What kind of piece would you be? Corner, curly, straight? I was sent a single piece this week, sent to URC ministers Every time you reach 35 years in the URC ministry, you receive a symbolic piece to show how you are part of the one church family Coming together as one family, united in peace, joining pieces together. When we take the small piece of bread, it reminds us we are all a part of the one body of Christ, building to make one huge picture together As reminders we have cards showing Faith, Hope, and Love with 4 questions for each day How have I acted with love today? How have I lived the life of Jesus today? How have I lived my faith today? How have I walked with hope today?
29:23 - 29:52 - Reading: Psalm 133 (Good News) 133 How wonderful it is, how pleasant, for God's people to live together in harmony! 2 It is like the precious anointing oil running down from Aaron's head and beard, down to the collar of his robes. 3 It is like the dew on Mount Hermon, falling on the hills of Zion. That is where the Lord has promised his blessing— life that never ends.
30:42 - 31:30 - Trinity Vision: Small Groups
31:54 - 34:12 - Trinity Vision: Midweek Café
34:20 - Songs R&S 565 Jesus stand among us TP 4 All heaven declares
40:33 - Introducing the readings The highest authority for what we believe and do is God’s Word in the Bible alive for his people today through the help of the Spirit. Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
41:13 - 42:07 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 12. 1 – 5, 12 – 13, 31 (NIVUK) 42:33 - Reaction to the reading
43:37 - Held together in the Body of Christ through the freedom of the Spirit, we rejoice in the diversity of the Spirit’s gifts and uphold the rights of personal conviction. For the sake of faith and fellowship it shall be for the church to decide where differences of conviction hurt our unity and peace. Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
42:10 - A Prayer of the unity and peace in the church family
45:35 - 47:30 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 13. 1 – 13 (NIVUK)
48:28 - Hymn - R&S 354 Come, Living God, when least expected
51:53 - 01:01:43 - Short Talk: ‘Faith, hope and love NOW’ Are you among the ardent youth or the mellow age? Most of us rather mellow Thinking of our anniversary, I tried to remember what it was like being 50 I remember being 40 more than 50 I was given an axe for my 50th birthday - in a pub! What is it like being 50 In the history of the Church, 50 is nothing really, even less in the history of humanity, it's just a blink of an eye Faith, Hope, Love since 1972 for the URC Paul's 1st letter to the Corinthians Ch 13. A difficult letter he was writing Replace the word "love" with "Jesus" to understand more Paul longs for people to reflect that love in their lives We believe in a loving God, not a condemning God We have many convictions, expressed in different ways yet we hold that common faith in a loving God and Jesus There are three things that last forever - faith, hope, and love and the greatest of these is love - hold on to that
01:01:49 - We affirm our intention to go on praying and working, with all our fellow Christians, for the visible unity of the Church in the way Christ chooses, so that people and nations may be led to love and serve God and praise him more and more, for ever. Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
01:02:47 - 01:04:50 - Prayers for the church and the world
01:04:55 - Hymn - R&S 469 As we are gathered Jesus is here
01:07:33 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Jesus Christ
01:07:33 - A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
01:10:52 - 01:17:23 - Distribution of Communion and Closing Prayer
01:17:24 - Hymn - R&S 603 Lord for the years
01:21:18 - 01:21:50 - Blessing
01:22:18 - 1:26:31 - Music and notices after the service
#communion #urc #vision #corinthians #jigsaw #FaithHopeLove #corner

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 18th September Harvest 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
15:07 - Welcome, introduction and call to worship
17:22 - Call to worship
17:52 - Hymn - Praise and thanksgiving (R&S 48)
20:16 - Opening Prayer of thanksgiving
22:17 - 28:04 - Introduction: ‘harvest links’ The harvest display connects us with people across the country and across the world Sunflower oil and sunflowers to creation and Ukraine An ear of wheat - gleaning the leftovers after harvest from the field behind Cores End church - farmers everywhere A coin - connecting to the Queen, thinking of the late Queen Elizabeth II and her family An envelope - connecting us with the people in Africa experiencing a vicious drought, supported by Christian Aid A can - connecting to One Can, our local foodbank supporting people in need
28:05 - 40:18 - One Can Update
40:25 - 42:21 - Reading: Psalm 65. 1, 5-13 (CEV)
42:51 - Song - Our God is a great big God
44:57 - Short Christian Aid Film: the Crisis in East Africa
47:56 - Prayer for East Africa Loving and compassionate God, When Famine stalks the land, nothing grows. Plants cannot, people cannot, ideas and dreams cannot everything withers and dies. It is a violent aberration of your will for the world and it is multiplied now by conflict, climate change and covid. God of the flourishing field, there is enough to feed us all. Call us to that sacred sharing, neighbour to global neighbour, your gifts of food, water, a chance to live the life so delicately crafted by your divine spirit. We will not turn away but turn towards each other with generosity and a justice-driven compassion that searches for solutions. Famine stalks the land, so may our outrage grow, may our determination steel itself, may our solidarity spur us into action. God of the flourishing field, help us feed each other. Amen.
50:26 - Song - Come all you people, come and praise your maker (video) Uyai mose, tinamate mwari. (x3) Uyai mose zvino.
Activity for children at back of church
52:45 - 54:05 - Reading: Luke 12 8.1 – 9 13 Someone in the crowd said to him, ‘Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me.’ 14 Jesus replied, ‘Man, who appointed me a judge or an arbiter between you?’ 15 Then he said to them, ‘Watch out! Be on your guard against all kinds of greed; life does not consist in an abundance of possessions.’ 16 And he told them this parable: ‘The ground of a certain rich man yielded an abundant harvest. 17 He thought to himself, “What shall I do? I have no place to store my crops.” 18 ‘Then he said, “This is what I’ll do. I will tear down my barns and build bigger ones, and there I will store my surplus grain. 19 And I’ll say to myself, ‘You have plenty of grain laid up for many years. Take life easy; eat, drink and be merry.’” 20 ‘But God said to him, “You fool! This very night your life will be demanded from you. Then who will get what you have prepared for yourself?” 21 ‘This is how it will be with whoever stores up things for themselves but is not rich towards God.’
54:42 - Song - Give thanks with a grateful heart (MP 170)
57:42 - 01:06:30 - Short Talk We live connected lives Our display connects us with many people - rich and poor, black and white, friends and enemies Many situations linked to us, we can not live in a vacuum The rich man in the parable tries this, no concern for his workers, just what to do with all his wealth - go for growth, growth, growth It could be a parable of the western world Jesus said to be on guard for all kinds of greed Life does not consist of an abundance of possessions Reflecting on the life of our Queen, we could say she was one of the top 0.1% in terms of wealth but looking at her lifetime of service, what she has done is incredible. "Each day is a new beginning, I know that the only way to live my life is to try to do what is right" Jesus said - whoever stores up things for themselves but is not rich towards God Let's speak to God today, come clean, and be challenged to live our lives better putting our trust in Our loving Saviour
01:06:32 - Hymn - God whose farm is all creation (R&S 612)
Offering of our gifts (symbolic gifts)
01:08:22 - Prayers of intercession for the world Lord of all the harvest Hear our prayer.
01:14:11 - The Lord’s Prayer
01:15:18 - Hymn - Fill your hearts with joy (MP 147)
01:18:39 - 01:19:04 - Blessing
01:19:29 - 01:22:35 - Music and notices after the service
#onecan #foodbank #queenelizabeth #tribute #harvest #creation #paddington #ukraine

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 11th September 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
00:12:40 Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
16:48 - Call to worship:
18:18 - Hymn - Our God our help in ages past R&S 705
21:51 - Opening Prayer
24:07 - The Lord’s Prayer
25:20 - 27:17 - Reading: Luke 15 vv 1-10 read by Norma Now the tax collectors and sinners were all gathering round to hear Jesus. 2 But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law muttered, ‘This man welcomes sinners, and eats with them.’ 3 Then Jesus told them this parable: 4 ‘Suppose one of you has a hundred sheep and loses one of them. Doesn’t he leave the ninety-nine in the open country and go after the lost sheep until he finds it? 5 And when he finds it, he joyfully puts it on his shoulders 6 and goes home. Then he calls his friends and neighbours together and says, “Rejoice with me; I have found my lost sheep.” 7 I tell you that in the same way there will be more rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous people who do not need to repent. The parable of the lost coin 8 ‘Or suppose a woman has ten silver coins[a] and loses one. Doesn’t she light a lamp, sweep the house and search carefully until she finds it? 9 And when she finds it, she calls her friends and neighbours together and says, “Rejoice with me; I have found my lost coin.” 10 In the same way, I tell you, there is rejoicing in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who repents.’
27:30 - 30:52 - Talk for All ages I remember the chaplain coming to my last place of work Misunderstanding the chaplain referring to us as a flock of sheep Driving home from Wales one night and a sheep ran out into the side of the road. God loves all of us and doesn't want any one of us to be lost Lots of things make us wander off from God Everyday life, tragedies etc. We can help by doing something that sheep do a lot - bleat, which for us translates to praying Remember the God forgives when we return to him and ask for forgiveness
30:54 - Hymn: Brother sister let me serve you R&S 474
34:28 - 36:07 - Reading: 1 Timothy 1 vv 12-17 read by Alan 2 I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who has given me strength, that he considered me trustworthy, appointing me to his service. 13 Even though I was once a blasphemer and a persecutor and a violent man, I was shown mercy because I acted in ignorance and unbelief. 14 The grace of our Lord was poured out on me abundantly, along with the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus. 15 Here is a trustworthy saying that deserves full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners – of whom I am the worst. 16 But for that very reason I was shown mercy so that in me, the worst of sinners, Christ Jesus might display his immense patience as an example for those who would believe in him and receive eternal life. 17 Now to the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only God, be honour and glory for ever and ever. Amen.
36:17 - Hymn: The King of love my shepherd is R&S 552
39:46 - 49:32 - Sermon followed by time of quite reflection We heard two parables today, the lost sheep and the lost coin Different but vividly illustrating the truth of John 3:16 - God so loved the world that he gave his only Son Both follow the same pattern: 1. Something is lost 2. There is a search for the thing that is lost 3. There is great joy when the thing that is lost is found How the things are lost are not important to the parables The items are regarded as precious by their owner, just as we are regarded by God Jesus is the shepherd not content to be happy with the 99, he will go out and look for the missing one God so loved us that whilst we were still sinners, he gave His Son We need a daily awareness of the gospel in our lives to keep us humble before our Saviour Do we look down on the sinners around us or do we seek the sinners as the lost needing to be found?
51:18 - Hymn: Eternal Father of the ceaseless round R&S 623
56:08 - Prayers of Intercession
01:00:35 - Hymn: God is love let heaven adore Him R&S 95
01:04:37 - 01:05:06 - Blessing
01:05:28 - 01:10:12 - Music and notices after the service
#queenelizabeth #photostory #worship #parables

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 4th September 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Music and notices before the service
08:16 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
09:35 - Call to worship: from Psalm 33 The world belongs to the Lord, the earth and all its creatures. Let everything that has breath praise the Lord; how good it is, to sing praises to our God.
10:24 - Hymn - R&S 45 Morning has broken
12:20 - Opening Prayer
13:34 - Introduction to Season of Creation for all ages: ‘Listen up!’ September sees the beginning of the season of creation Celebrated across the world by people from all kinds of backgrounds Christians in Pakistan suffering from floods Christians in East Africa suffering the worst drought in years Christians in Germany meeting at the council of World Churches Christians in Ukraine suffering from the invasion by Russia The season begins on the 1st September and continues to the 4th October, St Francis's Day This sense of relationship to the whole natural order goes back to the bible, one of the great Psalms speaks of creation which we will use now
15:53 - 17:35 - Reading: Psalm 19 The heavens declare the glory of God; the skies proclaim the work of God’s hands. Day after day they pour forth speech; night after night they reveal knowledge. Listen to creation tell of God, listen to God’s Word today They have no speech, they use no words; no sound is heard from them. Yet their voice goes out into all the earth, their words to the ends of the world. Listen to creation tell of God, listen to God’s Word today The law of the LORD is perfect, refreshing the soul. The statutes of the LORD are trustworthy, making wise the simple. The precepts of the LORD are right, giving joy to the heart. Listen to creation tell of God, listen to God’s Word today The commands of the LORD are radiant, giving light to the eyes. The fear of the LORD is pure, enduring forever. The decrees of the LORD are firm, and all of them are righteous. Listen to creation tell of God, listen to God’s Word today
17:35 - 18:04 - Listening is the theme of this year's season of Creation
18:28 - Creation video #seasonofcreation
23:30 - Prayer of lament with the response Lord in your mercy hear our prayer.
26:01 - Song MP 545 Open our eyes Lord, to see your creation, to care for this planet, the earth and its creatures. Open our ears Lord and help us to listen. O open our eyes, Lord; we want to love your world.
28:40 - Song Who put the colours in the rainbow? (JP 288)
31:14 - Introducing the readings
32:27 -35:01 - Reading: Exodus 3.1 – 12 (NIVUK) read by Ian Bogart
35:33 - Hymn - R&S 547 Moses I know you’re the man
39:50 - 41:15 - Reading: Mark 4:1-9 (Good News) read by Lesley Bogart
41:31 - 53:02 - Short Address: ‘Listen’ Geese flying over the house honking Energy and the cost of living crisis leading to lots of honking from politicians at the moment A call to listen is at the heart of our worship today To listen to the world around us and to God's voice Wordplay from Jesus in the parable "If you have ears, listen" The natural world is sending strong messages to us as the human race - wake up, protect from damage, turn back from the climate crisis Climate change first shown to be happening in 1939 but the message was delayed due to other events that year We have to listen to each other, the world, and God We have to protect His creation and liberating his people May we listen and may we act in Jesus' name
53:04 - Profession of Faith We believe in God, the Source of all life, who creates all things, who embraces all things, who celebrates all things, who is present in every part of the fabric of creation, who is and baptises this planet with living water. We believe in Jesus Christ, the Seed of new life, who loves and cares for this world and who suffers with it and for it and came to reconcile and renew this world and everything in it. We believe in the Holy Spirit, the Breath of God, who moves among and with us today. We believe in everlasting life in God, the living hope that one day God will put an end to death and all destructive forces. To the Living God, Trinity of Love, be all praise and glory, now and for evermore. Amen. (Gurukul Theological college, India - adapted)
54:22 - A Prayer for all creation
55:21 - Hymn - R&S 327 O God, who’s love’s undying flame
58:02 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Jesus Christ
A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
01:01:25 - Distribution of Communion
01:07:11 - Closing Prayer
01:10:54 - Hymn - R&S 60 God who spoke at the beginning (Tune 344)
01:13:00 - 01:13:23 - Blessing
01:13:58 - 01:16:51 - Music and notices after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 21st August 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
11:50 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
13:43 - Call to worship (based on Isaiah 58.9) Let us call out to God, and the LORD will answer; Let us will cry for help, and God will say: ‘here I am.’
14:06 - Hymn R&S 30 - Father we love you
16:42 - Opening Prayers with the response We rejoice in your presence: We give you thanks and praise.
Lord’s Prayer
20:55 - 27:33 - Introduction for all ages; ‘Awesome!’ What comes into your mind when you hear the word "awesome"? Teenagers maybe? It's a word for us all What do you find awesome? Or is the world so jaded we have lost our sense of awe? Sunsets, nature, God, Tour de France riders Awesome people: Skydivers, wheelchair racers at the Commonwealth Games, Malala Yousafzai Awesome nature: Sunrise, sunset, mountains and lakes, giant redwoods, murmurations of starlings Awesome universe: pictures from the James Webb telescope Behind our awesome creation is the awesome reality we call God God created all things, worthy of our worship
27:35 - Songs: MP 1005 Our God is an awesome God MP 242 Hosanna, hosanna
32:21 - Introducing the readings
33:45 - 34:30 - Reading: Psalm 103.1-8 NIVUK 1 Praise the LORD, my soul; all my inmost being, praise his holy name. 2 Praise the LORD, my soul, and forget not all his benefits – 3 who forgives all your sins and heals all your diseases, 4 who redeems your life from the pit and crowns you with love and compassion, 5 who satisfies your desires with good things so that your youth is renewed like the eagle’s. 6 The LORD works righteousness and justice for all the oppressed. 7 He made known his ways to Moses, his deeds to the people of Israel: 8 the LORD is compassionate and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in love.
34:38 - 36:47 - Reading: Hebrews 12. 49 – 56 18 You have not come to a mountain that can be touched and that is burning with fire; to darkness, gloom and storm; 19 to a trumpet blast or to such a voice speaking words that those who heard it begged that no further word be spoken to them, 20 because they could not bear what was commanded: ‘If even an animal touches the mountain, it must be stoned to death.’ 21 The sight was so terrifying that Moses said, ‘I am trembling with fear.’ 22 But you have come to Mount Zion, to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem. You have come to thousands upon thousands of angels in joyful assembly, 23 to the church of the firstborn, whose names are written in heaven. You have come to God, the Judge of all, to the spirits of the righteous made perfect, 24 to Jesus the mediator of a new covenant, and to the sprinkled blood that speaks a better word than the blood of Abel. 25 See to it that you do not refuse him who speaks. If they did not escape when they refused him who warned them on earth, how much less will we, if we turn away from him who warns us from heaven? 26 At that time his voice shook the earth, but now he has promised, ‘Once more I will shake not only the earth but also the heavens.’ 27 The words ‘once more’ indicate the removing of what can be shaken – that is, created things – so that what cannot be shaken may remain.
28 Therefore, since we are receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us be thankful, and so worship God acceptably with reverence and awe, 29 for our ‘God is a consuming fire.’
37:05 - Hymn MP 50 - Be still for the presence of the Lord
41:03 - 53:28 - Address What have we come to as we sit here or watch from home? A building where people have gathered Sunday by Sunday for 122 years - almost 9000 Sundays! A place where the service is uplifting, the music empowering, the preacher engaging? A group of people yes, but also this awesome God Political leaders come and go, wealth fades, athletic prowess diminishes, the world changes but at the heart of life, the one, unchanging God The one revealed to Moses - "I am who I am", the great "I am" The giving of the law on Mount Sinai was an awesome moment The writer to the Hebrews talks of Moses trembling in fear The Old Testament speaks again and again of fear of God being the beginning of all wisdom This God alone is worthy of worship The consuming fire of love, the light that blazes and drives away corruption, wipes away hatred & selfishness This is the worship God accepts today. Worship that flows into action, driving how we live day to day Let us take a moment to offer wonder, love, and praise to our awesome God.
53:30 - Silent reflection
53:57 - Offering Prayer for all our giving
54:28 - Hymn R&S 583 The Church is wherever
56:25 - Prayers for others and ourselves
01:02:49 - Hymn R&S 663 Love divine (1st tune Hyfrydol)
01:06:50 - 01:07:17 - Blessing
01:07:43 - 01:13:10 - Music and notices after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 14th August 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
09:46 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
12:56 - Call to worship
13:33 - HYMN - R&S 117 O Lord, my God, when I in awesome wonder
19:00 - Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
23:31 - 27:07 - Introduction for all ages How many of you have one of these - an Apostle Spoon? Whenever we visited an Aunt in childhood, a set of these would come out to look at I bought a set of 6 many years ago, all but one disappeared now They were originally given as gifts at the time of baptism as a symbol the person was a follower of Jesus or the hope that the child would become one Made of solid silver but likely not any more It reminds us that God is always close to hand if we follow Jesus
27:09 - Song MP 225 He’s got the whole wide world in His hands
29:12 - Introducing the readings
30:17 - Reading: Jeremiah 23. 23 – 29 NIVUK ‘Am I only a God nearby,’ declares the LORD, ‘and not a God far away? 24 Who can hide in secret places so that I cannot see them?’ declares the LORD. ‘Do not I fill heaven and earth?’ declares the LORD. 25 ‘I have heard what the prophets say who prophesy lies in my name. They say, “I had a dream! I had a dream!” 26 How long will this continue in the hearts of these lying prophets, who prophesy the delusions of their own minds? 27 They think the dreams they tell one another will make my people forget my name, just as their ancestors forgot my name through Baal worship. 28 Let the prophet who has a dream recount the dream, but let the one who has my
word speak it faithfully. For what has straw to do with grain?’ declares the LORD. 29 ‘Is not my word like fire,’ declares the LORD, ‘and like a hammer that breaks a rock in pieces?
31:40 - 32:55 - Reading: Luke 12. 49 – 56 49 ‘I have come to bring fire on the earth, and how I wish it were already kindled! 50 But I have a baptism to undergo, and what constraint I am under until it is completed! 51 Do you think I came to bring peace on earth? No, I tell you, but division. 52 From now on there will be five in one family divided against each other, three against two and two against three. 53 They will be divided, father against son and son against father, mother against daughter and daughter against mother, mother-in-law against daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law against mother-in-law.’ 54 He said to the crowd: ‘When you see a cloud rising in the west, immediately you say, “It’s going to rain,” and it does. 55 And when the south wind blows, you say, “It’s going to be hot,” and it is. 56 Hypocrites! You know how to interpret the appearance of the earth and the sky. How is it that you don’t know how to interpret this present time?
33:09 - Hymn R&S 317 Lord thy word, abideth
36:25 - 52:28 - Address When have you had to face something you didn't like but knew was going to happen Not knowing when or why, what were your emotions This is what Jesus was feeling in the gospel reading from Luke 12 He doesn't welcome the idea of what will happen in Jerusalem but accepts it Jeremiah says many people claim to speak from God but are false prophets He says the community is awash with false information about God Nowadays we hear a lot about fake news Today in our lifetimes, the truth about God is often hidden God's word is a word of judgement that Jesus brings Jeremiah says God's word is like a fire What is God really like? When our emotions are stirred, are they stirred by God or those around us?
Silent reflection
52:47 - Offering Prayer for all our giving
53:43 - Hymn R&S 567 Thy hand, O God, has guided
57:05 - Prayers for others and ourselves
01:03:22 - Hymn - R&S 373 Lord Jesus Christ, you have come to us
01:07:01 - 01:07:20 - Blessing
01:07:50 - 01:11:20 - Music and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 31st July led by Terry Hinks

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 31st July led by Terry Hinks
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music and notices before the service
09:24 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (by an elder)
11:01 - Call to worship (based on Hebrews 10) Let us come near to God with open hearts, for Jesus has opened for us a new and living way. Let us hold on firmly to the hope we profess, because we can trust God to keep his promise. Let us be concerned for one another, helping one another to show love and do good. Let us come together and encourage each other, more and more, as we follow Jesus here and now.
12:30 - Hymn - R&S 102 Praise the Lord, his glories show
15:42 - Opening Prayers with responses Lord have mercy: Lord have mercy. Christ have mercy: Christ have mercy. Lord have mercy: Lord have mercy.
19:08 - 27:30 - Introduction: a word from Lighthouse What is Lighthouse? When is it? Where is it held? Who is involved? What do we do? How can you help?
28:00 - Lighthouse Song (video)
32:43 - 34:18 - Reading: Psalm 98 NIVUK
Sing to the LORD a new song, for he has done marvelous things; his right hand and his holy arm have worked salvation for him. 2 The LORD has made his salvation known and revealed his righteousness to the nations. 3 He has remembered his love and his faithfulness to Israel; all the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God. 4 Shout for joy to the LORD, all the earth, burst into jubilant song with music; 5 make music to the LORD with the harp, with the harp and the sound of singing, 6 with trumpets and the blast of the ram’s horn – shout for joy before the LORD, the King. 7 Let the sea resound, and everything in it, the world, and all who live in it. 8 Let the rivers clap their hands, let the mountains sing together for joy; 9 let them sing before the LORD, for he comes to judge the earth. He will judge the world in righteousness and the peoples with equity.
36:31 - 38:24 - Reading: Hebrews 1. 1 – 8 NIVUK 1 In the past God spoke to our ancestors through the prophets at many times and in various ways, 2 but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom also he made the universe. 3 The Son is the radiance of God’s glory and the exact representation of his being, sustaining all things by his powerful word. After he had provided purification for sins, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty in heaven. 4 So he became as much superior to the angels as the name he has inherited is superior to theirs. 5 For to which of the angels did God ever say, ‘You are my Son; today I have become your Father’? Or again, ‘I will be his Father, and he will be my Son’? 6 And again, when God brings his firstborn into the world, he says, ‘Let all God’s angels worship him.’ 7 In speaking of the angels he says,
38:50 - 47:00 - Introducing the letter to the Hebrews (video) 47:04 - 47:57 - Summary of the reading and letter to the Hebrews
47:59 - Song: R&S 271 You are the king of glory
50:42 - Prayer
51:10 - 52:07 - Reading Hebrews 4.14 – 16 NIVUK 14 Therefore, since we have a great high priest who has ascended into heaven, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold firmly to the faith we profess. 15 For we do not have a high priest who is unable to feel sympathy for our weaknesses, but we have one who has been tempted in every way, just as we are – yet he did not sin. 16 Let us then approach God’s throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need.
52:10 - 01:00:39 - Talk: ‘Hold on!’ "Grace to help us in our time of need" As we look at the world right now, we see a time of great need The Ukraine, China, Taiwan, The Other Western Nations, The Climate Emergency, Environmental Need, Displacement due to conflict, the refugee crisis, doubt in the democratic process as our government attempts to regain trust and integrity, the cost of living crisis: surely this is a time of need But centuries ago these Jewish Christians, different to us in language, understandings, lifestyles. Think of their lives burdened by absolute poverty, unsure what persecution would arise in the brutal Roman Empire. They were in a time of need. Some questioned whether their faith was enough, some were slipping away The writer challenges them to hold on to the precious gift of Jesus given to them He was tempted but held on to his god even when all had deserted him Draw close the writer says, don't turn back, hold fast and come with confidence to your saviour Let the radiance of God's glory shine bright in your dark place and in the dark places of our world
01:00:50 - Offering Prayer (of all our gifts – no collection is taken up)
01:01:41 - Song R&S 375 In my life, Lord, be glorified
01:03:41 - Prayers for the church and the world with the response: Great God, in your mercy hear our prayer.
01:09:19 - Lord’s Prayer
01:10:08 - Hymn R&S 598 Will your anchor hold?
01:15:10 - 01:15:35 - Blessing
01:16:17 - 01:20:58 - Music and Notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 17th July led by Rev Terry Hinks

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 17th July led by Rev Terry Hinks
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music and notices
07:21 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
08:57 - Call to worship (from Hebrews 13)
God has said, ‘Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you.’ So we say with confidence, ‘The Lord is my helper; I will not be afraid. What can mere mortals do to me? Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and for ever. Therefore, through Jesus, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise and not forget to do good and to share with others.
09:48 - Hymn: R&S 377 This is the day!
12:32 - Opening Prayers with the response It is good to give thanks to you, our God: your love endures for ever.
15:10 - 24:12 - Introduction: ‘Time!’ We make it or waste it Where has the year gone? Coming in 2 minutes early Time to stay for refreshments afterwards Watching the clock too much? Images from the James Webb telescope, seeing images from things that happened thousands of years ago in the Southern Ring Nebula 8 minute for light from the sun to reach us Do you have time? Special thanks in this jubilee year for the URC, 50 years since the formation? Lighthouse starting in 1987 Our sanctuary refurbished in 2009
24:52 - 26:41 - Reading: Psalm 145. 1 – 13
26:54 - Song: Thank you Lord for this fine day! (Junior Praise 232)
30:45 - 35:55 - Introducing activity : 50 years of the United Reformed Church I hope 1972 is in your minds at the moment The union of Presbyterian and Congregationalist Christians that started the URC Congregational Union of Scotland joining in 2000 Activity: ‘50 year Time line’ 1972 – 2022 and beyond Think about 3 events to put on the timeline: a personal one, a special moment in the church, and an event in the community, nation or world
41:30 - Worship song: MP 1259 Bless the Lord o my soul
45:44 - Introduction to reading
46:16 - 47:35 - Reading: Luke 4.14 – 21 (The Message)
47:47 - 52:42 - All age talk: ‘The Time is now!’ What a moment that must have been - that synagogue where Jesus read the words from Isaiah saying what he was about For the United Reformed Church, this is seen as a jubilee year, when we want God's time to shine Anniversary socks from the URC Ministers' gathering What else can you buy that's URC branded - soap! Jesus gives his agenda in the moment in Galilee - a very particular place and moment The Spirit of the Lord is upon me - to bring good news to the poor God's time is now Good news can't just be words, it has to be actions The story ends with Jesus being turned out and a crowd attempting to stone him Moments of jubilation and despair on our timeline Is God shining through Jesus and hist followers We need to open our eyes to find where that light is shining in unexpected places
54:58 - Song: MP 545 Open my eyes Lord
55:55 - Short talk: Vision for Trinity Key themes from the planning group - worship and Christian discipleship Outward looking, communicating the good news of Jesus Focusing on the resources we have - buildings, finance and people Working in partnership Start small - crawl, walk, then run Doing something, not remaining paralysed
Offering Prayer (of all our gifts – no collection is taken up)
59:08 - 01:00:11 - Song Open my hands Lord Open our hands, Lord, we want to serve Jesus, to reach out in his name, and show his love for all. Open our hearts, Lord, and help us to follow. Open our hands, Lord, we want to serve Jesus.
01:00:16 - Prayers for the church and the world with the response Your kingdom come Your will be done. Lord’s Prayer (modern version)
01:06:48 - Hymn R&S 489 Be thou my vision
01:10:10 - 01:10:39 - Blessing
01:11:03 - 01:14:55 - Music and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 24th July led by John Shaw

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 24th July led by John Shaw
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music and notices before the service
15:18 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (by an elder)
17:29 - Call to Worship from Colossians 2. 6 – 7
19:09 - Hymn When morning gilds the sky (R&S 292)
22:40 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
25:15 - 34:07 - Talk for all ages: “Teach us to pray” We are glad it's not as hot as last Monday and Tuesday When it's that hot, it's hard to even think, one just wants to be still and get through it Think about a time when you had to learn a skill Sometimes the learning is successful, sometimes not Learning to tie shoelaces? Learning to play the piano? Learning to drive? In the reading from Luke's gospel, the disciples want Jesus to teach them how to pray. In Luke more than others, we hear of when Jesus is praying We have already used the prayer he taught them all two thousand years ago There is so much in the Lord's Prayer What he taught them was not what they were expecting which was something long and wordy What Jesus taught was a simple prayer, the short version of this can be said just in one breath If ever you are uncertain of how to pray, the Lord's Prayer is a great place to start
34:22 - Hymn - Father I place into your hands (R&S 518)
34:50 - Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities: Adults: May the Lord be with you Junior Church: And also with you All: Amen.
37:53 - Introduction to Bible readings
38:23 - Reading: Luke 11. 1 – 13 NIVUK 11 One day Jesus was praying in a certain place. When he finished, one of his disciples said to him, ‘Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples.’ 2 He said to them, ‘When you pray, say: ‘“Father, hallowed be your name, your kingdom come. 3 Give us each day our daily bread. 4 Forgive us our sins, for we also forgive everyone who sins against us. And lead us not into temptation.”’ 5 Then Jesus said to them, ‘Suppose you have a friend, and you go to him at midnight and say, “Friend, lend me three loaves of bread; 6 a friend of mine on a journey has come to me, and I have no food to offer him.” 7 And suppose the one inside answers, “Don’t bother me. The door is already locked, and my children and I are in bed. I can’t get up and give you anything.” 8 I tell you, even though he will not get up and give you the bread because of friendship, yet because of your shameless audacity ] he will surely get up and give you as much as you need. 9 ‘So I say to you: ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened to you. 10 For everyone who asks receives; the one who seeks finds; and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened. 11 ‘Which of you fathers, if your son asks for a fish, will give him a snake instead? 12 Or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion? 13 If you then, though you are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father in heaven give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!’
40:35 - 42:43 - Reading: Colossians 2. 6 – 15 NIVUK
43:03 - Hymn - I will sing the wondrous story (CMP 315)
46:52 - Prayer 47:46 - 01:05:06 - Sermon: “Ask and you will receive” These familiar words are used just after the Disciples ask Jesus to teach them how to pray They highlight how important it is for us to ask, seek, knock and pray Why do some people say prayer is irrelevant Looking at prayer in the context of our relationship with God Finally thinking about the nature of God that sets the words in context Distinguishing between gifts from God as creator and father - creation and redemption
A time of quiet reflection
01:06:00 - Hymn - What a friend we have in Jesus (R&S 413)
01:08:56 - Prayers for others and ourselves Offering Prayer of all our gifts – no collection is taken up
01:15:18 - Hymn - At the name of Jesus (R&S 261)
01:18:34 - 01:18:54 - Closing blessing / the Grace
01:19:22 - 01:23:08 - Organ voluntary and notices

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 10th July led by Dr J Prior

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 10th July led by Dr J Prior
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Music and notices before the service
10:50 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder) 12:18 - Call to worship
13:47 - Hymn: R&S 45 Morning has broken [Tune: Bunessan]
15:59 - Opening Prayers Lord’s Prayer
18:54 - 23:40 - Talk with all ages - Prophets Our first reading will be from one of the Old Testament Prophets Do any of our young people understand what prophets One that prophesies, something where you spend money to make more money Homophones and prophets/profits We all profit from the wisdom of the prophets Prophets weren't actually telling the future, their job was to tell it like it is Speaking truth to power and telling those in power that things were not going as they should be Thinking of modern day prophets Greta Thunberg - a schoolgirl but understands the world as it is today is not going to be able to sustain itself unless we change.
23:55 - Song TP 13 Be still, for the presence of the Lord
27:05 - Offering Prayer (of all our gifts – no collection is taken up)
Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities: Adults: The Lord be with you Junior Church: And also with you All: Amen.
29:10 - Introduction to the readings
30:21 - Reading: Amos 7:7-17 NIVUK
33:32 - 35:35 - Reading: Colossians 1: 1 – 14 NIVUK
35:45 - Song: TP 13 God forgave my sin
38:31 - 50:48 - Address: How to live a good life which honors God The two bible readings could hardly be more different Separated in time by about 800 years, the tone of the two is markedly different Amos wrote his prophecy in around 760BC some 20 years before the better known Isiah Amos didn't see himself as a prophet, not employed by anyone important, he worked the land. He traveled widely and knew the northern kingdom well. He saw lots of inequality and divisions in society Merchants were paying lip service only to their religion The Altar at Bethel was being used to worship false Gods When he challenged the High Priest, Amos was told to go back to Judah Amos warned that Israel's exile to Assyria was at had but was ignored There are sad parallels with our society today Our Prime Minister Boris Johnson wriggling out of one scandal after another. Now irretrievably rejected by his MPs he has accepted he needs to go but is still clinging to power. Brought down by his own dishonest. Think of Putin's invasion of Ukraine and the war crimes committed there. Think of the riots in Sri Lanka Think of the earthquake in Afghanistan and all of the other issues there Paul's letter to the Colossians is in contrast to this. Written from house arrest in Rome whilst waiting for false accusations to be dealt with. It is full of hope, written to stem the influence of teaching aimed at trapping the people in superstition We are still Paul's congregation We have been rescued by God through Christ Jesus, forgiving our sins. Paul's message helps us to bear in mind that God in Christ Jesus is all in all, first and last, head of the Church, all powerful and generous in return for our faith and obedience to God's law - loving him with all our strength, soul, and mind and to love our neighbour as we love ourself
51:04 - Hymn R&S 613 Lord, speak to me [Tune: RS 50; Galilee]
54:41 - Prayers of intercession with the response Leader: The Lord hears our prayer: All: Thanks be to God.
59:47 - Hymn R&S 260 Christ is alive! [Tune: Truro]
01:03:12 - 01:03:45 - Final Prayer and Blessing
01:04:45 - 01:07:45 - Organ voluntary and notices

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 3rd July led by Rev Terry Hinks

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 3rd July led by Rev Terry Hinks
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music and notices before the service 05:05 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
06:28 - Call to worship: from Psalm 66
07:27 - Hymn: TP 48 Jesus calls us here to meet him
10:40 - Opening Prayers with the response
13:30 - 22:33 - Introduction: ‘receiving and sharing the gift’ Good to be back home Think for a moment about a house - a childhood home, where you live today, a holiday home, a tent, a famous place Buckingham Palace, the Queen welcoming a refugee from Peru at her recent Diamond Jubilee celebrations Jesus sending out 72 disciples out to visit villages and homes taking a great gift - Peace Peace doesn't just appear, it has to be made
23:35 - Worship songs: R&S 594 Peace perfect peace (vs 1 only) and MP 1227 The splendour of the King – led by Music Group
28:50 - Introduction to the readings
29:25 - 30:37 - Reading: Luke 10:1 – 11 NIVUK
31:20 - Hymn R&S 512 Seek ye first the kingdom sung seated as a round
35:04 - 35:48 - Reading: Luke 10: 17 – 21 NIVUK
36:52 - Hymn R&S 286 Rejoice in the Lord sung standing as a round
38:53 - 47:45 - Short Address Take a deep breath, relax, be conscious of the in-breath, hold and then release Slowly breathe in and out feeling the air moving Difficulty living with asthma The breathing of the church The church as Institutions and people of God Inviting others to come and breathe in the love of God Living our christian and human lives day by day Keeping in balance Jesus trusting the disciples with his work Using the words "Peace to this house"
47:47 - Hymn R&S 398 O Lord hear my prayer sung seated to begin our prayers
50:16 - 52:28 - Prayers for others and ourselves Please pray for: • Those on your hearts who need God’s peace • Trinity Prayer Day – as we seek God’s guidance for our Church Vision – our work and witness in our community. • Lighthouse Holiday Club (25 – 29 July) • URC General Assembly meeting at Swanwick (8 to 11 July) • Peace in homes, nations and globally
52:37 - Hymn R&S 635 Put peace into each other’s hands
56:20 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ, empowered by the Spirit.
A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
Distribution of Communion and Closing Prayer
01:06:14 - Hymn R&S 21 Praise God from all blessings flow
01:07:18 - 01:07:50 - Blessing
01:08:27 - 01:13:06 - Music, photos and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 26th June 2022 led by Daisy Mansfield The Leprosy Mission

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 26th June 2022 led by Daisy Mansfield The Leprosy Mission
media:group.media:description:
00:00 Music and notices before worship.
09:39 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
11:55 - Call to worship: Psalm 118
13:24 - Hymn: TP 12 Be still and know that I am God
15:17 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
16:55 - 21:12 - Talk for all ages: Introduction to the Leprosy Mission Difficulties with leprosy Leprosy a bacterial disease affecting hands and feet
21:18 - Worship songs MP 1079 Jesus Hope of the nations MP 1008 The Lord’s my Shepherd I’ll not want
Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities:
29:13 - Introduction to Bible readings
29:35 - Reading 1 : Isaiah 43:14-21
31:07 - 32:53 - Reading 2: John 10: 1-10 r
33:06 - Hymn TP 100 When we walk with the Lord
36:52 - Sermon – Springs of Hope Bringing a message of hope in 3 parts: An unexpected hope, a living hope, and partnered in hope Poppies as a sign of hope Niger and the issues with poverty and leprosy How education is changing lives Donations helping transform communities £6 provides a child with a place at school for a year
01:00:02 - A time of quiet reflection
01:01:30 - Hymn TP29 For I’m building a people of power
01:04:11 - Prayers for others and ourselves
Offering – please stand for the Prayer of Dedication
01:10:41 - Hymn TP 31 Give thanks with a grateful heart
01:13:43 - 01:14:06 - Closing blessing
01:14:28 - 01:17:58 - Music and notices after the service
Organist: Charles Brewster
